message_1: Consider the algebraic variety defined by the equation $y^2 = x^3 + x^2$. Calculate the cohomology group $H^1(\mathbb{C}\setminus V,T)$, where $V$ is the variety and $T$ is the sheaf of holomorphic tangent vectors.
message_2:
To compute the cohomology group $H^1(\mathbb{C}\setminus V, T)$, we will use the exponential sequence of sheaves:

$0 \to \mathbb{Z} \to \mathcal{O} \to \mathcal{O}^* \to 0$

Here, $\mathcal{O}$ is the sheaf of holomorphic functions and $\mathcal{O}^*$ is the sheaf of nonzero holomorphic functions. Taking the long exact sequence of cohomology, we get:

$0 \to H^0(\mathbb{C}\setminus V, \mathbb{Z}) \to H^0(\mathbb{C}\setminus V, \mathcal{O}) \to H^0(\mathbb{C}\setminus V, \mathcal{O}^*) \to H^1(\mathbb{C}\setminus V, \mathbb{Z}) \to H^1(\mathbb{C}\setminus V, \mathcal{O}) \to H^1(\mathbb{C}\setminus V, \mathcal{O}^*) \to \cdots$

Since $\mathbb{C}\setminus V$ is connected, $H^0(\mathbb{C}\setminus V, \mathbb{Z}) = 0$ and $H^0(\mathbb{C}\setminus V, \mathcal{O}) = \mathbb{C}$. Also, $H^0(\mathbb{C}\setminus V, \mathcal{O}^*) = \mathbb{C}^*$, so the map $H^0(\mathbb{C}\setminus V, \mathcal{O}) \to H^0(\mathbb{C}\setminus V, \mathcal{O}^*)$ is surjective. Thus, we have:

$0 \to H^1(\mathbb{C}\setminus V, \mathbb{Z}) \to H^1(\mathbb{C}\setminus V, \mathcal{O}) \to H^1(\mathbb{C}\setminus V, \mathcal{O}^*) \to \cdots$

Now, we use the fact that $H^1(\mathbb{C}\setminus V, \mathcal{O}) = 0$ since $\mathbb{C}\setminus V$ is a Stein manifold. Therefore, we have:

$0 \to H^1(\mathbb{C}\setminus V, \mathbb{Z}) \to 0 \to H^1(\mathbb{C}\setminus V, \mathcal{O}^*) \to \cdots$

This implies that $H^1(\mathbb{C}\setminus V, \mathbb{Z}) \cong H^1(\mathbb{C}\setminus V, \mathcal{O}^*)$. To compute $H^1(\mathbb{C}\setminus V, \mathcal{O}^*)$, we use the fact that the first Chern class $c_1$ of the holomorphic line bundle associated to $\mathcal{O}^*$ is an isomorphism:

$c_1: H^1(\mathbb{C}\setminus V, \mathcal{O}^*) \to H^2(\mathbb{C}\setminus V, \mathbb{Z})$

Since $V$ is a smooth curve of genus $1$, we have $H^2(\mathbb{C}\setminus V, \mathbb{Z}) \cong \mathbb{Z}$. Thus, we have:

$H^1(\mathbb{C}\setminus V, \mathcal{O}^*) \cong \mathbb{Z}$

Now, we can compute the cohomology group $H^1(\mathbb{C}\setminus V, T)$ using the following short exact sequence of sheaves:

$0 \to T \to \mathcal{O}^2 \to \mathcal{O}^* \to 0$

Taking the long exact sequence of cohomology, we get:

$0 \to H^0(\mathbb{C}\setminus V, T) \to H^0(\mathbb{C}\setminus V, \mathcal{O}^2) \to H^0(\mathbb{C}\setminus V, \mathcal{O}^*) \to H^1(\mathbb{C}\setminus V, T) \to H^1(\mathbb{C}\setminus V, \mathcal{O}^2) \to H^1(\mathbb{C}\setminus V, \mathcal{O}^*) \to \cdots$

Since $H^0(\mathbb{C}\setminus V, T) = 0$ and $H^1(\mathbb{C}\setminus V, \mathcal{O}^2) = 0$, we have:

$H^1(\mathbb{C}\setminus V, T) \cong H^1(\mathbb{C}\setminus V, \mathcal{O}^*) \cong \mathbb{Z}$

Therefore, the cohomology group $H^1(\mathbb{C}\setminus V, T)$ is isomorphic to $\mathbb{Z}$.
